Given the patient’s recent camping trip and consumption of meats and water from local sources, it is possible that he acquired an infection that led to ulcers and, subsequently, bleeding in the intestinal tract. However, given the patient’s history of colon cancer, it is also possible that the bleeding is caused by a malignancy. Surgical removal of malignant tissue or surgical resection of a portion of the colon may be appropriate depending on the underlying cause of the bleeding, but more information is needed to make this determination. Therefore, cautery of an arteriovenous malformation is the most appropriate treatment at this time, as it is a common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding in elderly patients and can be diagnosed and treated via colonoscopy and endoscopic therapy.
